$schema: Keyword cluster definitions for the Politech Awards 2026 scoring algorithm
methodology: Each cluster is derived from an established UK policy framework. Keyword matches against project URLs produce a weighted bonus score. This is a URL-based proxy heuristic — see 'tradeoffs' for known limitations.

clusters.name: Digital Inclusion / Exclusion
clusters.framework: Good Things Foundation + DCMS Digital Inclusion Strategy (2014, refreshed 2024)
clusters.rationale: Projects addressing digital exclusion directly target populations unable to access government services online — a core barrier to civic participation.

clusters.name: Socio-economic Vulnerability
clusters.framework: Joseph Rowntree Foundation (JRF) UK Poverty Framework
clusters.rationale: Projects serving economically vulnerable populations address structural barriers to political engagement and public service access.

clusters.name: Public Service Access / Gov Access
clusters.framework: Local Government Association (LGA) Digital & Service Transformation frameworks
clusters.rationale: Projects improving access to public services address the gap between service availability and population reach, especially for those navigating complex bureaucracies.

clusters.name: Marginalised Communities
clusters.framework: Equality Act 2010 Protected Characteristics + Social Exclusion Unit legacy categories
clusters.rationale: Projects serving communities that face structural discrimination are directly relevant to political technology's mission of equitable civic participation.

false_positives: URL substring matching is context-blind: 'benefits' could mean employee benefits rather than welfare benefits
'council' could appear in non-UK contexts (e.g. 'council-of-europe' unrelated to local authority services)
'nhs' could match in unrelated strings (e.g. a domain containing 'nhs' by coincidence)
'gov' will match any .gov domain regardless of whether the project improves public access
'debt' may appear in financial industry projects unrelated to poverty
Projects with keyword-rich URLs may score highly without actually serving the target population
false_negatives: Projects genuinely addressing exclusion may not have relevant keywords in their URL
URL-based matching cannot assess project quality, reach, or actual impact
Hyphenated keywords (e.g. 'digital-inclusion') may not match URLs using other separators like underscores or camelCase
Non-English project URLs will not match English-language keywords
Abbreviated or colloquial terms (e.g. 'UC' for Universal Credit, 'DV' for domestic violence) are not matched
mitigations: Random base score (1-100) ensures non-matching projects still receive a meaningful score
Per-cluster caps prevent any single cluster from dominating the total bonus
Match details are included in results.json for full transparency and auditability
Keyword clusters and weights are stored in a separate, human-readable JSON file for independent inspection
Each cluster cites a specific policy framework, making the political assumptions explicit and contestable
The committee can adjust weights, caps, and keywords via PR — each change goes through the voting process
